In number theory, a composite number is a positive integer that has at least one positive divisor other than one or the number itself. In other words, a composite number is any number that is not prime. Composite numbers are the building blocks of all other numbers, as any number greater than 1 can be expressed as a product of prime numbers. 

There are several ways to classify composite numbers based on their prime factorization. For instance, a perfect square is a composite number whose square root is an integer. A perfect cube is a composite number whose cube root is an integer. Other types of composite numbers include the product of two or more prime numbers.

One of the key properties of composite numbers is their divisibility. A composite number is always divisible by at least one other number, making it a crucial concept in divisibility tests and prime numbers. 

Some examples of composite numbers include:

- 4 (2 × 2)
- 6 (2 × 3)
- 8 (2 × 2 × 2)
- 12 (2 × 2 × 3)

One historical example of successful collaboration between experts from different fields is the work of Johannes Kepler and Johannes Matthaeus Meyfart. Kepler, an astronomer, was trying to determine the orbital periods of planets in the solar system. Meyfart, an optician and lens maker, created a device called the camera obscura that projected images of the sun onto a wall. This device allowed Kepler to make precise measurements of the sun's angular motion, providing crucial data for his groundbreaking work on planetary motion.

Another example is the collaboration between Norman Borlaug and M.S. Swaminathan. Borlaug, a plant pathologist and agronomist, developed high-yielding wheat varieties that revolutionized agriculture and reduced hunger in many parts of the world. Swaminathan, a biochemist and geneticist, worked with Borlaug to develop these high-yielding crops, which were resistant to certain diseases. Their work led to the development of the Green Revolution and had a significant impact on global food security.

Interdisciplinary research has also led to the development of sustainable agriculture practices, such as precision agriculture, which combines expertise from agronomy, computer science, and biology to optimize crop yields and reduce environmental impact.
